column501: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td id=""introduction"" class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column515: >Amazon S3 is an object storage service used to store the data and using S3 we can host our website on S3, so let just host a website in S3.
column535: > An active AWS account
column539: > A registered domain name
column559: >create a S3 bucket with the same name of as of your domain
column563: >choose ACL disabled in Object Ownership.
column567: >upload index.html file and grant Public read access.
column571: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column590: >Select the bucket and go to the Properties section and Enable Static website hosting and add the name of index document, you can add an error document as well.
column594: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column609: >In you aws management console search Route53 service, in the DNS Management section click on create hosted zone.
column610: >Enter your domain name and select type of hosted zone as public then click create.
column614: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column622: >Once you created the hosted zone you will get 4 nameserver.
column633: >Navigate to your domain registrar console and for the registered domain click on option for change Nameserver
column638: >Add the 4 nameserver entry that you got after creating hosted zone.
column648: >Create Record in Route53
column652: > once nameservers are updated, back to your aws console and in the created hosted zone click on create record
column666: > select the Record type A (this type of record sends traffic to IP address, but we don&#39
column667: t have webserver running on EC2 having public IP, we will use alias)
column671: > enable Alias and and select Alias to S3 website endpoint.
column675: > Choose S3 region (where your bucket is )
column679: > and select the S3 endpoint then click on create record.
column689: > test your website by typing URL in the browser.
column693: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column707: > make sure that you create a bucket first before purchasing the domain, because the bucket names are globally unique.
column719: >Happy learning.👋

column439: > Managing a Database in Kubernetes

column501: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""""><tr><td bgcolor=""transparent"" style=""background-color:transparent
column503: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column507: >Containerized environments are designed primarily for stateless applications. In these setups, pods are identical — created and destroyed dynamically with random names and hashes — and a Service routes traffic evenly to any available pod.
column509: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column513: >However, databases are inherently stateful. They cannot be created or destroyed randomly, and their pods are not interchangeable. In a typical master-worker (primary-replica) database architecture:
column515: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td style=""padding-bottom:12px
column529: >Only one pod (the master) handles read and write operations.
column533: >Replica pods provide read-only access and continuously synchronize data from the master.
column537: >
column539: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column543: >To manage these different needs:
column545: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td style=""padding-bottom:12px
column559: >We use Deployments for stateless applications.
column563: >We use StatefulSets for stateful applications like databases.
column567: >
column569: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column575: >Problem Statement
column577: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column581: >While StatefulSet ensures pods are uniquely identifiable and maintain their state across restarts, building a proper master-replica database architecture still requires extra logic:
column583: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td style=""padding-bottom:12px
column597: >Ensuring only one master pod with full read/write access.
column601: >Managing replica pods for read-only operations and automatic data replication.
column603: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column607: >Handling this setup manually can be complex and error-prone — a challenge often faced by DevOps Engineers.
column611: >
column613: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column619: >Introduction to Controllers
column621: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column625:
>To simplify managing databases on Kubernetes, we can use custom controllers (operators).
These controllers automate complex tasks like:
column627: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td style=""padding-bottom:12px
column641: >Electing a master pod.
column645: >Setting up read replicas.
column649: >Handling failovers if the master goes down.
column653: >Managing data replication.
column655: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column659: >With just a few installation steps (deploying a Helm chart or manifest), these controllers take care of the heavy lifting for you.
column661: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column665:
>Examples of database operators/controllers:
 CloudNativePG — for PostgreSQL clusters.
 MySQL Operator — for MySQL databases.
column667: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column671: >These solutions make running production-grade databases inside Kubernetes much easier, more reliable, and scalable.
column677: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td height=""10"" style=""line-height:1px

column539: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td id=""introduction"" class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column549: > To interact with the Kubernetes cluster you install kubectl (a command line utility), and you run the command kubectl apply -f pod.yaml or kubectl run my-pod --image=nginx . when you run the command your request goes to the API server and then the request proceeds.
column553: > but, how kubectl know to which cluster it has to send the request, and if the request is sent how will API-Server figure out whether this request is coming from a valid user or not? Let&#39
column554: s understand it in this blog.
column556: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column562: >What is a kubeconfig file?
column564: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column569: font-family:__Inter_a184c8, ui-sans-serif, system-ui, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, ""Segoe UI"", Roboto, ""Helvetica Neue"", Arial, ""Noto Sans"", sans-serif, ""Apple Color Emoji"", ""Segoe UI Emoji"", ""Segoe UI Symbol"", ""Noto Color Emoji""
column572: >when you create a Kubernetes cluster you get a config file, by default in path ~/.kube/config
column574: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td style=""padding:0px 15px

column3: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column9: >Key Components of a Kubeconfig File
column11: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column15: >let’s understand the different attributes of config file.
column17: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td style=""padding-bottom:12px
column31: >clusters: contains the information about Kubernetes clusters including the certificate authority and url of the server.
column35: >user: contains information about user , kubernetes itself does not manage users rather it depends on external authentication mechanisms like certificate-based authentication or External Identity provider.
column39: >context: maps users and clusters.
column43: >current-context: contains the context that will be executed, when the command is run on kubectl.
column45: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""padding-bottom:20px
column49: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column53: border=""0""/>
column55: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column59: >How kubectl Interacts with the Kubernetes API Server
column61: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column66: s understand how it works when you run the command kubectl get pods
column68: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td style=""padding-bottom:12px
column80: >kubectl will see on current context to which API-Server as which user request has to be sent.
column84: >The request goes to API-Server.
column88: >API Server will validate request using Authentication Authorization and Admission.
column90: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column96: >Authentication Authorization and Admission
column98: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column102: >Authentication: Validate whether the user is valid or not, depending on his key and certificate.
column104: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column108: >Authorization: Authorize weather you are allowed to perform that task or not, authorization is performed depending on role and role-binding.
column110: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column114: >Admission: The admission controller does certain things validate: checks whether the request has the correct structure and format. mutate: automatically fills the missing fields. depending upon the rules if admission is successfully completed.
column116: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column122: >Pod scheduling and running
column124: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column128: >kube-scheduler then find best-fit node and schedule the pod to run on that node. then kubelet on that node with help of container runtime creates pod and sends update to API-Server. and communication between different components of Kubernetes happens throug API-Server.
column130: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" valign=""top"" style=""color:#2A2A2A
column136: >Outro
column138: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column142:
>So the next time when you run kubectl apply -f pod.yaml you know what happens!
kubectl using the configuration in the kube-config file sends a request to the API server, The API server then performs authentication, authorization and admission then the kube-scheduler schedules it in the best-fit node, kubelet deploys the pod and sends report to API-Server.
column144: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column148: >thanks for reading and happy learning. 👋
